>>21276974
This study doesn't actually exist. The only reference to it comes from James Clear in his book Atomic Habits (where it's framed as a pottery class) but iirc there's no citation there either. The truth is quantity does not trump quality (as evidenced by the millions of words written by fan fiction authors and amateur web novelists that never get any better). If you really want to improve you need to work fewer hours with more focus and intensity. You need to apply the principles of deliberate practice: break down the activity into sub-skills, then train those sub-skills, (starting with your weakest), via repeatable drills that provide immediate feedback.

In the past, novice writers would be able to get feedback (even if only in the form of rejection) by submitting to the numerous magazines that were available. Before that, there were writer's groups, either in universities or private clubs (or even family, e.g the Bronte sisters), where they would share their writing with each other. Nowadays the options are limited. Magazines are on the decline, publication is biased by identity politics, and writing groups have moved online (and are filled with overly sensitive types that barely know the rudiments).

What you can do instead is to try and learn by imitation. A dozen or so of your favorite volumes of literature, emblematic of the kind of material you want to produce, can take you to a professional level very quickly. But you have to train in a systematic way. I've seen people on this board recommend things like just typing out the words of a novel or taking notes while reading. These are not sufficient. Something like the Franklin Method is closer to the point. On the more extreme side there's things like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uT81Q3osi8c (I don't necessarily recommend such detailed abstraction). A middle ground would be an exercise like the following (taken from: https://usermanual.wiki/Pdf/Michael20KardosThe20Art20and20Craft20of20Fiction20A20WriterE28099s20GuideBedfordSt20MartinE28099s202012.2011509823.pdf):
>First, analyze a short story to uncover the function of each of its sections. Then write an original story, with your own characters, plot, voice, et cetera, in which each section of the story serves the same structural purpose as in the story you analyzed. Compare to the original.

You may wish to start with individual paragraphs instead of jumping straight into an entire short story. Likewise, you may want to focus on passages that address your weaknesses first (e.g dialogue, or transitional summaries between scenes, or establishing the setting, etc). 10 hours spent in this kind of focused work is 10X as valuable as 100 hours spent "just writing", but is also 10X as hard, which is why only a few people do it.

last_replies.com:
the word used in book 1 is κοιμᾶθ', with the last vowel ellided (and the long alpha switched from an eta)
the LSJ provides "lull to sleep" and "lie to sleep" as definitions; in the middle, "lay himself in order to sleep" is a reasonable definition
the word used in book 2 is εὗδον, from εὕδω, and whose semantic range is pretty much just sleep (again check the LSJ)
so basically, while they *can* contradict, Homer uses two different verbs between what Zeus does and what all other gods and men do.

threads.sub: 20 most common errors by young authors according to Lovecraft
threads.com:
>Erroneous plurals of nouns, as vallies or echos.
>Barbarous compound nouns, as viewpoint or upkeep.
>Want of correspondence in number between noun and verb where the two are widely separated or the construction involved.
>Ambiguous use of pronouns.
>Erroneous case of pronouns, as whom for who, and vice versa, or phrases like “between you and I,” or “Let we who are loyal, act promptly.”
>Erroneous use of shall and will, and of other auxiliary verbs.
>Use of intransitive for transitive verbs, as “he was graduated from college,” or vice versa, as “he ingratiated with the tyrant.”
>Use of nouns for verbs, as “he motored to Boston,” or “he voiced a protest.”
>Errors in moods and tenses of verbs, as “If I was he, I should do otherwise,” or “He said the earth was round.”
>The split infinitive, as “to calmly glide.”
>The erroneous perfect infinitive, as “Last week I expected to have met you.”
>False verb-forms, as “I pled with him.”
>Use of like for as, as “I strive to write like Pope wrote.”
>Misuse of prepositions, as “The gift was bestowed to an unworthy object,” or “The gold was divided between the five men.”
>The superfluous conjunction, as “I wish for you to do this.”
>Use of words in wrong senses, as “The book greatly intrigued me,” “Leave me take this,” “He was obsessed with the idea,” or “He is a meticulous writer.”
>Erroneous use of non-Anglicised foreign forms, as “a strange phenomena,” or “two stratas of clouds.”
>Use of false or unauthorized words, as burglarize or supremest.
>Errors of taste, including vulgarisms, pompousness, repetition, vagueness, ambiguousness, colloquialism, bathos, bombast, pleonasm, tautology, harshness, mixed metaphor, and every sort of rhetorical awkwardness.
>Errors of spelling and punctuation, and confusion of forms such as that which leads many to place an apostrophe in the possessive pronoun its.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
#1 - Facticity and Freedom Edition

The goal of this general is to discuss existentialism and phenomenology, two interconnected traditions in 19th and 20th century continental philosophy. Of special interest is discussion of existentialist phenomenology in particular (roughly the same as existentialism proper), though discussion of non-existentialist phenomenology (such as Husserl) is also welcome. Ignore shitposters and trolls. Be respectful, don't shitfling. Any questions are welcome.

>Facticity and Freedom
This is a common theme in existentialist philosophy. The idea is that there are two parts to the human condition. On the one hand, we are immanent, in the world, as the totality of objective facts. This is also called "facticity." It is the facts that are true about us. We share this with the rest of the world's inhabitants (objects, animals, etc). On the other hand, as human beings there is a second aspect, we are transcendent and go beyond the facts about us, having an inward, subjective experience, we are importantly free. This is also known as "freedom." Many existentialist authors have further things to say about this duality, and how it relates to authenticity, to alienation, to anxiety, and so forth. Thoughts and questions welcome.

last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21280845
>Is there a literary equivalent of this?

Probably quite a few. A few sort-of examples:

Philip Larkin got fed-up with everyone endlessly repeating This Be The Verse. It's a fairly minor poem (one of his worst, in my opinion) and normies just fixated on it because of the bad language, and ignored all his really good stuff.

William Faulkner became (in)famous for Sanctuary (because of the Rape By Corncob, obviously). It was written just to make money, and is definitely one of his worst books. But by the time of his death his genuine masterpieces had overtaken it, so he wans't as badly off as Tchaikovsky.

D. H. Lawrence was certainly most (in)famous for Lady Chatterley when it finally got published. But that was after he died. Not sure it's his worst book but it's very far from his best.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've read Journey to Ixtlan. The third book.

You are making some leaps of logic with left, demons and evil. Yes, death is over the left shoulder, an arm's length away. Yes, left is associated with the occult, and evil, but also simply unorthodox or hidden paths. Death is certainly a mystery, and a fearful thing. The left makes sense.

Death is the wise advisor because you can turn to him at any time and ask him "Is this my time?". Mostly it will not be your time. So you keep on living.

The whole point of the Death example is to point you towards a feeling, a state of mind, that he wants to get you to tap into. This was best exemplified, for me, in the section of Ixtlan where he is made to face the tiger/lion. The feeling of good living is one of urgency, as though every moment is your last. And it may well be your last. So keep Death in mind. Live fully, now. This state of mind is found in many mystical writings. It is essentially being present, 'now', it's a fluid state where you make no second guesses and act instinctively with courage in spite of the fear. Finding this feeling and learning to maintain it is the key to good living for Castaneda, as well as the key to magic for him, and also for other mystical traditions.

As for your bit about 'lover killer', well, I think an essential part of love is dying. In occult writings they speak of dying before death to fully live. A man must die twice. Love itself, also, could be seen as dying as you pour your essence into another, you live for another, you essentially move the point of your soul into another location, in the same way that Jung spoke of his goal of individuation being to move the consciousness from the ego to the Self (Self here being the witness, or God-mind. Individuation for Jung was equal to deification).

>Hodge (fl. c.1769) was one of Samuel Johnson's cats, immortalised in a characteristically whimsical passage in James Boswell's 1791 book Life of Johnson.
Although there is little known about Hodge, such as his life, his death, or any other information, what is known is Johnson's fondness for his cat, which separated Johnson from the views held by others of the eighteenth century.
>" I never shall forget the indulgence with which he treated Hodge, his cat: for whom he himself used to go out and buy oysters, lest the servants having that trouble should take a dislike to the poor creature. I am, unluckily, one of those who have an antipathy to a cat, so that I am uneasy when in the room with one; and I own, I frequently suffered a good deal from the presence of this same Hodge. I recollect him one day scrambling up Dr. Johnson's breast, apparently with much satisfaction, while my friend smiling and half-whistling, rubbed down his back, and pulled him by the tail; and when I observed he was a fine cat, saying, "Why yes, Sir, but I have had cats whom I liked better than this;" and then as if perceiving Hodge to be out of countenance, adding, "but he is a very fine cat, a very fine cat indeed." This reminds me of the ludicrous account which he gave Mr. Langton, of the despicable state of a young Gentleman of good family. "Sir, when I heard of him last, he was running about town shooting cats." And then in a sort of kindly reverie, he bethought himself of his own favourite cat, and said, "But Hodge shan't be shot; no, no, Hodge shall not be shot."

Reminds me of an experience I had watching the best horror film I have ever seen with some friends who are not into horror. I was immersing myself in the experience, they were resistant to it because they are scared easily in general, and they actually came out thinking the movie was stupid and comical. A man in the theater literally booed it at the end. Since then it's been recognized by almost everyone else by an excellent film.
Better still, one of the friends who thought it was stupid, during one of the more suspenseful scenes, actually covered his face with a sweater.

So your capacity to experience horror in a story, just like your capacity to identify with love, religious experience, or anything else, depends on your openness or resistance to the feelings in question. People who are afraid of fear dislike horror. I make the effort to feel the most horror I can when I engage horror - I have to, because I am not a fearful person at all.

Milton shies away from God speaking off the hip, if you will, about his justifications as it's kind of impossible to justify. This has the result of him (unfairly, giving the nature of the Trinity) trying to use Jesus as the humanist straightman who plays the good cop to God's bad cop.

The thing that strikes me most about PL is just after Adam has fallen and is lamenting his lot, when he starts talking about how he never asked to be born, never desired persistence beyond his fall, and the nonnecessity of his punishment given God's omnipotence. The bit that strikes me is just how clearcut Milton renders the question of existence without religion. Without: worthless; With: barely justifiable as long as it doesn't result in a greater good that otherwise.

Generally people underrate the deviance that historical persons had from strict dogma, supposing them incapable, then, by stupidity or obstinacy or whatever, of the free thought needed to realise the inconsistencies in Christian belief; this, failing to not just how needed the belief actually was, and how little other game in town there was for eschatological (which then was 100% needed to spur the getting out of bed every morning) meaning.

I think once Adam and Eve are introduced in full, Satan becomes much, much less sympathetic and you can see how much of a bastard he is for destroying their beautiful ignorance. Of course, the real question that Milton doesn't explore that much in the book is: Why would God create Adam and Eve with free will, tell them not to eat the apple of knowledge, and then punish them, all with perfect knowledge that this was going to happen? I've only read Paradise Lost once and I'm not familiar with the ins and outs of Christian theology, especially the theological arguments of whatever branch of Protestantism Milton followed, so I'm just kind of shooting from the hip here, but having an all-seeing God who is supposed to be all good and everywhere at once I think ends up shooting Christianity in the foot because it implies that God knows ahead of time of all evil that will ever happen, does nothing to stop it, and then punishes them that do evil deeds. It seems very arbitrary and inconsistent. But maybe that's what Milton's hidden message is in the book: God is NOT omnibenevolent and is completely outside of our understanding of morality and logic.

>Even a quick glance at a map of the United States would suggest that a significant portion of its literature would deal with rural people, places, and concerns. There should be many of novels of small towns and country houses, as Russia and Britain produced in the 18th and 19th centuries when they were still deeply rural societies. However, this is not the case. Rural settings are only ever exploited as places of danger for urban or suburban protagonists, and their denizens are suspicious and vile. The crime genre (as well as literary fiction centered around crime) gravitates to small towns and portrays them as dens of murder and hypocrisy despite the fact that large cities are usually far more dangerous. Only a handful of working authors, almost all of them over 50 and rural born, portray the vast hinterlands of the USA with any measure of sympathy. The rest of the literary elite are islanded in a handful of mega-metropolitan areas and, it must be said, do not view the provincials as their countrymen, nor, often, as full human beings. They write about them in the same manner that colonizers write of the colonized, but feel no shame because they have no empathy for anyone outside of their few preferred zip codes.
-Charles Bladnecke, Modern Age, Fall 2022

#1 - Frege edition

The goal of this general is to read analytic philosophy as history, encouraging rather than supressing dialogue between it and both historical and continental philosophy. As such we will focus more on insights of widest scope that have been made in analytic philosophy. However, discussion of anything and everything analytic is welcome. Discussion of historical/continental parallels are welcome, so long as both sides don't resort to flinging shit at each other. Ignore shitposters and trolls. Be respectful. Any questions are welcome.

>Frege
Frege is the founder of the tradition and far more insightful than even analytics themselves realize. They're only now catching up to him on some of these respects. Some good books worth reading eventually:
>The Frege Reader
>The Foundations of Arithmetic (Grundlagen der Arithmetik)
>Frege: Philosophy of Language, by Michael Dummett

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21281054
Interesting, are you familiar with the Warsaw School of Logic? One of the most important analytic logicians, Alfred Tarski, came from that, he moved to the United States later and influenced many analytics. Other Warsaw logicians were also influential. Stanislaw Lesniewski was the founder of contemporary mereology, especially when cast in a formal language. The Warsaw School was founded by Kasimierz Twardowski who was a student of Franz Brentano, who also taught Husserl and another proto-analytic (Alexius Meinong), so there's some connection there to both analytic and continental history.
>>21280942
I don't know of a good pre-history book like you're describing but I can try to tell you a pre-history myself, not an expert but I have some idea. Dummett's book is fantastic but long and difficult, so it's worth a look eventually, however maybe not as a direct first introduction to Frege (I am OP).
>Husserl
I feel what happened here that led to continental 20th century philosophy is that, though he was sort of doing stuff similar to analytics initially, mostly making very conservative (relative to the later phenomenologists) analyses of mental experience, later phenomenologists basically got much more creative and especially turned to analyzing aspects of lived experience (like for example, anxiety) that go well beyond what analytics tend to focus on (for better or worse). So that's what Heidegger, Sartre, and so forth are doing. Here their antecedents really are Kierkegaard and Nietzsche, more than Husserl, since Kierkegaard was basically doing proto-phenomenology, giving analyses of anxiety, faith, irony, and other feelings and lived experiences. Nietzsche is also similar, and what he's doing analyzing moral conscience on the one hand, and even our use of categories like susbtance, causation, oneness, etc, is kind of like what Heidegger and Sartre do. Other proto-phenomenologists like Kant and Hegel are also important to them. Husserl kind of limits himself to Kant I think, and so does Frege, they're of course both going past Kant sometimes, critiquing him, etc. But you don't see Frege engage Hegel, Kierkegaard, etc.
>pre-history
The main thing necessary is to understand Kant, and especially knowing the neo-Kantians were becoming a thing around the time, since Frege is willing to grant that geometry might be synthetic a priori, but he strongly rejects seeing arithmetic as synthetic. He is more influenced by Leibniz when he conceives of them as analytic, this shows through in the Grundlagen/Foundations of Arithmetic. His next main influence was Cantor, who came up with the modern notion of a set and began set theory. He was also reacting against some mathematicians (Hilbert later is a good example) who saw mathematics as just the manipulation of symbols according to some rules, and thus not as objective or truth-apt. And he of course is responding to Kantians in another way, by rejecting psychologism, heir to transcendental idealism.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21280942
>>21281634
(Con't)
If you are interested in knowing proto-analytic history,not always leading up directly to Frege but still foreshadowing other things, I recommend you look into the following names: Herbart, Bolzano, Comte, Bentham, Mill, Sidgwick, the neo-Kantians, Avenarius, Mach, Brentano, Meinong, and Dilthey. Also Peirce, James, Dewey. Maybe even Green, Bradley and McTaggart (I'll explain).
>neo-Kantianism
These guys like Cohen and Natorp and later Cassirer are indicative of a revival of pre-Hegelian Kantianism in the later 19th century. What people like Frege and Russell were doing was in a way continuing this return to Kant and earlier, but in their own ways.
>early positivism
This is Comte as well as utilitarians like Bentham, Mill, Sidgwick, and the "empirio-critical" German positivists like Avenarius and Mach. Comte aside (not sure about him) these guys were phenomenalists, so it's a nice link between Hume (the first phenomenalist) and later ones like the middle-stage Russell, logical positivists like Schlick and the early Carnap, and other sense data theorists like C.I. Lewis and H.H. Price. Mach was very influential to the early positivists, while Mill was Russell's godfather.
>Brentano circle
Brentano may have influenced Frege. Meinong certainly influenced Russell directly. Since Husserl was Brentano's student it's also good to check out how this is the origin of the divide. Brentano has influenced later analytics because of his views on intentionality, which also influenced continentals via Husserl. So in a weird way he, rather than Kant, is the last philosopher they both share. Chisholm is an analytic who especially likes Brentano, but he matters to many in philosophy of mind.
>Bolzano
This guy is basically Frege before Frege, and influenced Frege, Brentano, others. He argues that propositions exist as abstract objects, and is a good bridge from Kant to Frege.
>Herbart
Totally forgotten now but he's the earliest example of how not all post-Kantian philosophy was Hegel/Schopenhauer idealism and the stuff that came out of that. Herbart was coming up with mathematizations of psychology and has interesting views like his theory of color blending. Probably the earliest proto-analytic in spirit, but didn't influence anyone other than being anti-psychologistic apparently.
>Dilthey
Very influential to Carnap. Also influential to continentals, mainly via Heidegger. As weird as it seems Carnap and Heidegger are actually very very similar, and it probably owes to Dilthey.
>pragmatists
Peirce was doing symbolic logic stuff. With James and Dewey, they're antecedents of the constructivist and neo-pragmatist brand of analytic philosophy, especially in America (Goodman, Quine, Sellars, Davidson, Putnam, Rorty), so quite influential. The connecting link was C.I. Lewis, a late pragmatist who directly engaged early analytics.
>British idealism
Though they're very continental-esque, a few of their ideas still influenced analytics.

>>21281691
(Con't 2)
The British idealists influenced analytics as follows. T.H. Green had some ideas about the meaning of life (perfectionism) and about aesthetics, which have been strangely influential to analytics recently. F.H. Bradley's famous "Bradley's regress" has mattered quite a bit to analytics. And most famously of all, J.M.E. McTaggart gave an argument against the reality of time which lays down the basic idea of A-theory vs. B-theory of time, which has been very influential to analytics. Lastly, these guys (at least Bradley that I know of) make some interesting anti-psychologistic arguments in response to sense data positivists like Mill, which are interesting foreshadowing of stuff analytics like Frege would probably like.

>Interesting, are you familiar with the Warsaw School of Logic? One of the most important analytic logicians, Alfred Tarski, came from that, he moved to the United States later and influenced many analytics. Other Warsaw logicians were also influential. Stanislaw Lesniewski was the founder of contemporary mereology, especially when cast in a formal language. The Warsaw School was founded by Kasimierz Twardowski who was a student of Franz Brentano, who also taught Husserl and another proto-analytic (Alexius Meinong), so there's some connection there to both analytic and continental history.
I had some lectures on Tarski and his meta language (because I picked philosophy of Truth as a chosen subject for a two semesters), but didn't hear anyone call it Warsaw School of Logic, or maybe it's just foreigners that call it that. But then we're going to have Polish Philosophy taught at the last, so I am going to learn that at some point. However, I recall someone mentioning that Husserl's philosophy resembled a polish philosopher's views, and that the polish guy was first. Maybe that's what you're referencing. But I'm not that interesting in polish philosophy, I got into it to widen my horizonts and understanding, not to learn of particular philosophers, so I'm rather ignorant about its history and branches of thought.
